events.title: Cremation pyre in Africa thought to be world’s oldest containing adult remains
events.summary:
9,500-year-old pyre uncovered in Malawi offers rare insight into rituals of ancient African hunter-gatherer groups

A cremation pyre built about 9,500 years ago has been discovered in Africa, offering a fresh glimpse into the complexity of ancient hunter-gatherer communities.

Researchers say the pyre, discovered in a rock shelter at the foot of Mount Hora in northern Malawi, is thought to be the oldest in the world to contain adult remains, the oldest confirmed intentional cremation in Africa, and the first pyre to be associated with African hunter-gatherers.

events.title: US ‘adapt, shrink or die’ terms for $2bn aid pot will mean UN bowing down to Washington, say experts
events.summary:
Afghanistan and Yemen excluded from list of 17 priority countries chosen by Trump administration to receive aid laden with demands

The $2bn (£1.5bn) of aid the US pledged this week may have been hailed as “bold and ambitious” by the UN but could be the “nail in the coffin” in changing to a shrunken, less flexible aid system dominated by Washington’s political priorities, aid experts fear.

After a year of deep cuts in aid budgets by the US and European countries, the announcement of new money for the humanitarian system is a source of some relief, but experts are deeply concerned about demands that the US has imposed on how the money should be managed and where it can go.

The head of Guinea’s junta, Mamady Doumbouya, who had pledged not to run for office after seizing power four years ago, has been elected president after the country’s electoral commission said he had secured a sweeping majority of the vote.

Doumbouya, 41, faced eight rivals for the presidency but the main opposition leaders were barred from running and had urged a boycott of the vote held over the weekend.

events.title: Tensions between Saudis and Emiratis over future of Yemen reach boiling point
events.summary:
Dispute has potential to create civil war in south of Yemen and spill over into neighbouring countries

Tensions between the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia over the future of Yemen and the imminent possibility of the declaration of an independent southern state have reached boiling point with Saudi Arabia in effect accusing the UAE of threatening its future security.

The dispute has the potential to create a civil war within the south of Yemen and also spill over into other disputes including in Sudan and the Horn of Africa where the two countries often find themselves backing opposite sides. Yemen could yet become only one theatre in which the two vastly wealthy Gulf states vie for political influence, control of shipping lanes and commercial access.

events.title: Why has US attacked Caracas and captured Venezuela’s president?
events.summary:
Trump’s unprecedented capture of Nicolás Maduro follows months of military campaign and years of strained relationship

• US attacks Venezuela – live updates

Overnight Friday, the US carried out airstrikes across Venezuela, with explosions rocking the capital, Caracas, before dawn. Shortly afterwards, Donald Trump announced that US forces had captured the Venezuelan president, Nicolás Maduro, and his wife, Cilia Flores, and had flown them out of the country.

The stunning attack and unprecedented capture of a sitting president follow months of an intense US pressure campaign against Venezuela. Since September, the US navy has amassed a huge fleet off the Venezuelan coast and carried out airstrikes against alleged drug-trafficking boats in the Caribbean and the Pacific and seized Venezuelan oil tankers. At least 110 people have been killed in the strikes on boats, which human rights groups say could amount to war crimes.

Venezuelan officials have accused the US of trying to gain access to the country’s oil reserves, the largest in the world.

The bombardment of Venezuela and the capture of Maduro is a serious and dramatic escalation of the US campaign. The future of Venezuela’s ruling regime remains uncertain.

Continue reading...

events.title: Venezuela attack: what we know so far as Trump claims Maduro captured
events.summary:
US president confirms attack on Venezuela and says Nicolás Maduro and wife Cilia Flores have been flown out of country

•​ US strikes on Venezuela – live updates

The US president, Donald Trump, has said Venezuela’s dictator, Nicolás Maduro, and his wife, Cilia Flores, have been captured and flown out of the country after a “large scale” pre-dawn assault on Caracas and the surrounding region. Here is what we know so far:

Donald Trump has claimed the US has “captured” Venezuela’s dictator, Nicolás Maduro, and his wife, Cilia Flores, and flown them out of the South American country after a pre-dawn assault on Caracas and the surrounding region. The US president said a press conference will be held in Florida at 11am local time (4pm GMT).

Venezuela’s government accused the US of launching a series of attacks against civilian and military targets in the South American country, after explosions rocked its capital, Caracas, before dawn on Saturday.

In a statement, Venezuela’s government urged citizens to rise up against the assault and said Washington risked plunging Latin America into chaos with “an extremely serious” act of “military aggression”. “The entire country must mobilise to defeat this imperialist aggression,” it added.

Explosions and low-flying aircraft were heard in Caracas in the early hours of Saturday. In its statement, Venezuela’s government confirmed that the city had come under attack, as well as three other states: Miranda, La Guaira and Aragua.

Venezuela has accused the US of trying to “seize control” of the country’s resources, in particular its oil and minerals. Venezuela has called on the international community to denounce what it called a flagrant violation of international law that puts millions of lives at risk.

In the early hours of Saturday, the president of neighbouring Colombia, Gustavo Petro, called for an immediate emergency session of the UN security council, saying on social media that Venezuela had come under attack.

The K-pop record label Ador is suing a former member of megaband NewJeans for millions in damages, it has announced, a day after removing her from the group following a year-long dispute that saw the band allege mistreatment and attempt to leave their contract.

Nearly 60 female lawmakers in Japan, including the prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, have submitted a petition calling for more toilets in the parliament building for women to match their improved representation.

Japanese politics remains hugely male-dominated, although the number of women in the parliament rose at the last election – and Takaichi became the first female prime minister in October. This is reflected by there being only one lavatory containing two cubicles for the lower house’s 73 women to use near the Diet’s main plenary session hall in central Tokyo.

events.title: Teenage girl educated in Britain among the missing after Crans-Montana fire
events.summary:
Charlotte Niddam, 15, went to school in Hertfordshire and her family have not heard from her since the blaze

A teenager educated in Britain is among those missing after a deadly fire in a Swiss ski resort.

Charlotte Niddam, 15, lived in Bushey, Hertfordshire, until recently and attended Immanuel college, a private Jewish secondary school in the town. The school issued a statement on Friday saying it was “praying for a miracle for Charlotte”.

Continue reading...

events.title: ‘Suspension of entry into the US’, paparazzi – and wine: three other reasons George Clooney moved to France
events.summary:
A UK government warning that Amal Clooney risks US sanctions over her role in the issuing of an arrest warrant for the Israeli prime minister is key among reasons the couple have sought French citizenship

The exodus from Hollywood to shores not presided over by Donald Trump has been busy and loud. Ellen DeGeneres, Robin Wright and Courtney Love moved to England; Rosie O’Donnell opted for Ireland; Eva Longoria, Spain. Other Trump critics, including Richard Gere, Lena Dunham and Ryan Gosling, have upped sticks without citing the re-election as a motivating factor.

In the case of Clooney, however, there has appeared little doubt that his decision to gain French citizenship was primarily because of Trump, whose re-election he energetically campaigned against. Yet amid the heat and headlines generated by the pair’s war of words, some of the actor’s reasons for relocating may have flown under the radar.

Continue reading...

events.title: Switzerland resort fire ‘likely started by sparklers in champagne bottles’, says attorney general – as it happened
events.summary:
Officials say 40 people were killed and 119 injured, with some in hospital still unidentified due to ‘horrific’ injuries

Italy’s ambassador to Switzerland Gian Lorenzo Cornado has said that all bar five of the 112 injured have been identified now, reports Reuters. Swiss officials are yet to give an update on this and have not shared the names of any victims or injured.

Six Italians are still missing and 13 hospitalised, he added. Three Italians were repatriated on Thursday and three more will follow on Friday, he said.

It’s the grief, as if we have all lost a loved one.

Continue reading...

events.title: Sparklers held near ceiling started Swiss ski resort fire, investigators believe
events.summary:
Footage and witness statements show blaze that killed about 40 was ‘very rapid’, prosecutor says

Investigators believe fountain sparklers mounted on champagne bottles and held too close to the ceiling sparked the deadly fire that tore through a crowded bar in the ski resort of Crans-Montana, killing about 40 people and injuring more than 100.

“Everything suggests the fire started from the burning candles or ‘Bengal lights’ that had been attached to champagne bottles,” the prosecutor Béatrice Pilloud said on Friday. “These went too close to the ceiling.”

Continue reading...

events.title: ‘No future for us’: disaffected Iranians say it’s now or never to topple regime
events.summary:
Ailing economy sparks biggest uprising in years, with protesters saying it’s time to hit regime when it’s at its weakest

Mehnaz was too young to protest when Mahsa Amini died in police custody three years ago after she was arrested for allegedly wearing the hijab improperly. Her mother did not let her join the throngs of crowds chanting “woman, life, freedom” in Tehran and across the country – so she could only watch at home as they were beaten back by batons and bullets.

Since then, the 19-year-old computer science student in Tehran has waited for the chance to join fellow Iranians in protest. On Sunday, the moment finally came.

Continue reading...

events.title: Tents supplied to displaced Palestinians ‘inadequate for Gaza winter’
events.summary:
Thousands have blown down in storms and tents from China, Egypt and Saudi Arabia found to be not waterproof

Thousands of tents supplied by China, Egypt and Saudi Arabia to shelter displaced Palestinians in Gaza offer only limited protection against rain and wind, an assessment compiled by shelter specialists in the devastated territory has revealed.

The assessment will undermine claims that Palestinians in Gaza are being supplied with adequate shelter. Fierce storms in recent weeks blew down or damaged thousands of tents, affecting at least 235,000 people, according to UN estimates.

Continue reading...

events.title: Saudi invites Yemen’s southern factions to ‘dialogue’ in Riyadh after surprise independence bid
events.summary:
Southern Transitional Council wants to form a breakaway state, which would split the Arabian Peninsula’s poorest state in two

Saudi Arabia’s foreign ministry has called for Yemen’s southern factions to attend a “dialogue” in Riyadh, after a surprise independence bid and the United Arab Emirates declaring it had withdrawn all troops from Yemen.

In a statement on Saturday, the Saudi ministry urged “a comprehensive conference in Riyadh to bring together all southern factions to discuss just solutions to the southern cause”. Riyadh said the Yemeni government had issued the invitation for talks.

Continue reading...

events.title: BBC settles with 7 October survivors for filming home ‘without permission’
events.summary:
Jewish family say crew did not seek consent to film inside their home days after it was wrecked by Hamas in southern Israel

The BBC has said it has reached a settlement with a Jewish family who survived Hamas’s 7 October attacks in southern Israel after a news crew filmed inside their destroyed home.

The reporting team, which included senior correspondent Jeremy Bowen, entered the Horenstein family’s home in the days after the attacks in 2023.

Continue reading...

events.title: Israel accuses Mamdani of antisemitism on first day as New York mayor
events.summary:
Foreign ministry says mayor has poured ‘antisemitic gasoline on an open fire’ by scrapping IHRA definition

Israel’s foreign ministry has accused the New York mayor, Zohran Mamdani, of pouring “antisemitic gasoline on an open fire” after he reversed a recent order by the outgoing mayor, Eric Adams.

“On his very first day as @NYCMayor, Mamdani shows his true face: he scraps the IHRA definition of antisemitism and lifts restrictions on boycotting Israel. This isn’t leadership. It’s antisemitic gasoline on an open fire,” the foreign ministry said in a post on X.

Continue reading...

events.title: Ministers cannot go on ignoring the Shamima Begum case, for two important reasons
events.summary:
The fate of the woman who left the UK at 15 in search of Islamic State raises wider questions about citizenship

While many aspects of UK political polling have shifted drastically since 2019, the public’s view on Shamima Begum has remained largely fixed: a big majority do not want the now 26-year-old woman back in the UK.

In 2019, Sajid Javid, then home secretary, stripped the Londoner of her UK citizenship on the grounds that she was a security threat, having travelled as a schoolgirl with two friends to territory controlled by Islamic State (IS) in Syria. At the time, 76% of people backed the move.

Continue reading...

events.title: Sewage in drinking water blamed for at least 10 deaths in India’s ‘cleanest city’
events.summary:
Hundreds hospitalised in Indore after public toilet built above water pipeline appears to have let sewage into supply

Sewage-contaminated drinking water is being blamed for killing at least 10 people, including a baby boy, and sending more than 270 others to hospital in Indore, ranked India’s “cleanest city” for the last eight years.

Residents of a congested, lower-income neighbourhood in Indore, Madhya Pradesh’s commercial capital, had been warning authorities for months about foul-smelling tap water. Their complaints went unheeded, despite the city’s much-lauded ranking for waste segregation and other cleanliness measures.

Continue reading...

events.title: Khaleda Zia, first female Bangladesh prime minister, dies aged 80
events.summary:
Zia’s archrivalry with Sheikh Hasina defined the country’s politics for a generation

Khaleda Zia, the first female prime minister of Bangladesh whose long rivalry with Sheikh Hasina defined the country’s politics for a generation, has died aged 80.

Zia was one of the most significant and divisive political figures in the country since Bangladesh independence 50 years ago. Her death was announced on Tuesday morning by the Bangladesh Nationalist party (BNP).

Continue reading...

events.title: Polls close in first phase of Myanmar elections widely condemned as a sham
events.summary:
Turnout appears low for vote in which most candidates seen as allies of junta and large areas excluded by war

Polls have closed in conflict-racked Myanmar, ending the first phase of an election that has been widely condemned as a sham designed to legitimise the military junta’s rule.

The military has touted the vote as a return to democracy almost five years after it seized power in a coup, ousting the country’s then de-facto leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, detaining her and sparking a spiralling civil war.

Continue reading...

events.title: Nepal TV host and ex-rapper mayor form alliance for election after youth revolt
events.summary:
Kathmandu mayor Balendra ‘Balen’ Shah will run for prime minister with presenter Rabi Lamichhane’s party after deadly protests that ousted government

Two of Nepal’s most popular political leaders have formed an alliance ahead of next year’s election in the wake of deadly youth-led protests earlier in the year that ousted the government.

Television host Rabi Lamichhane, the 51-year-old chairperson of the Rastriya Swatantra party (RSP), and the 35-year-old rapper turned Kathmandu mayor Balendra Shah pledged to address the demands of the younger generation following September’s deadly anti-corruption protests.

Continue reading...

events.title: Growing numbers of over-60s facing homelessness, charities warn
events.summary:
Housing crisis reaches UK’s oldest generations as high private rents and lack of social housing hits pensioners

The housing crisis has reached the country’s oldest generations, charities have warned, with a growing number of people over the age of 60 seeking help for homelessness.

Housing charities said they had seen cases of people over-60 developing health problems from being forced to sleep in their car for months, having to sleep on camp beds in emergency shelters and seeking homelessness support even while suffering illnesses such as cancer.

Continue reading...

events.title: Feeling the bite: is Greggs on a roll or is its expansion overbaked?
events.summary:
UK pastry chain has plans for two new factories and 800 more branches, despite sales falling in 2025 and analysts questioning brand’s direction

An enormous carpet of pastry snakes its way around the factory. Four huge metal urns of meat filling are waiting to be added. Workers in hairnets and overalls buzz about, checking a production line that holds 4.5 tonnes of pastry at any one time.

This is food production on an industrial scale, designed to satisfy the UK’s seemingly insatiable appetite for sausage rolls, vegan bites and other baked treats.

Continue reading...

events.title: Second body recovered from sea off Withernsea as search resumes for third person
events.summary:
Humberside police say body retrieved off East Yorkshire on Friday evening amid rescue operation in ‘horrendous conditions’

A second body has been recovered from the sea off the coast of Withernsea, East Yorkshire, as the search resumes for a third missing person.

Humberside police said the body of a second person was retrieved on Friday evening. Earlier, a 67-year-old man had been pulled unconscious from the water, but he died later.

Continue reading...

events.title: Reddit overtakes TikTok in UK thanks to search algorithms and gen Z
events.summary:
Platform is now Britain’s fourth most visited social media site as users seek out human-generated content

Reddit, the online discussion platform, has overtaken TikTok as Britain’s fourth most visited social media service, as search algorithms and gen Z have dramatically transformed its prominence.

The platform has undergone huge growth over the last two years, with an 88% increase in the proportion of UK internet users it reaches. Three in five Brits online now encounter the site, up from a third in 2023, according to Ofcom.

Continue reading...

events.title: ‘We will grind you down’: how rogue peers became Labour’s toughest opponents
events.summary:
As Labour seeks abolition of hereditary peers, Tory-dominated House of Lords has inflicted near-record number of defeats on No 10

Dining in the House of Lords canteen just after Labour came to power, one Labour adviser found themselves sitting opposite two Tory peers.

In particular, the pair were fuming about the forthcoming abolition of hereditary peers. Both agreed, the adviser said, that there should be a deliberate strategy to undermine the government on all its legislation, to slow down debate, and to push the new Lords leader, Angela Smith, to ask No 10 for concessions.

Continue reading...

events.title: US woman charged with fetal homicide after allegedly inducing own abortion
events.summary:
Kentucky woman reportedly ordered medication to end her pregnancy and buried remains in her yard

A Kentucky woman is facing multiple criminal charges after she allegedly induced her own abortion using medication.

Kentucky state police arrested the woman, Melinda S Spencer, 35, on charges of fetal homicide in the first degree, abuse of a corpse and tampering with physical evidence, according to a local Kentucky news outlet. Spencer reportedly ordered medication online to end her pregnancy, then buried the remains of her pregnancy in her backyard.

Continue reading...

events.title: US’s first registry of domestic abusers takes effect in Tennessee
events.summary:
‘Savanna’s law’ named after woman killed by ex-boyfriend, who had extensive record of domestic violence allegations

A state law creating the first registry of people convicted of domestic abuse in the US took effect Thursday in Tennessee.

Named after Savanna Puckett, a woman who was shot to death by her ex-boyfriend in January 2022, “Savanna’s law” requires the Tennessee bureau of investigation to maintain a database of people who have been convicted of or pleaded guilty to at least two domestic violence offenses.

Continue reading...

events.title: College freshman identified as one of three hikers found dead on California’s Mount Baldy
events.summary:
Marcus Alexander Muench Casanova, 19, died on the Devil’s Backbone trail after reportedly falling 500ft

A 19-year-old college freshman has been identified as one of the hikers whose remains were found on California’s Mount Baldy on Monday.

The San Bernardino county sheriff announced this week that Marcus Alexander Muench Casanova, a resident of Seal Beach, California, was discovered along a mountain trail known as the Devil’s Backbone.

Continue reading...

events.title: DC pipe bomb suspect must remain in jail before trial, judge rules
events.summary:
Brian Cole, accused of planting bombs before Capitol attack, presents ‘intolerable risk of danger’, court finds

A federal magistrate judge has ruled that the man accused of planting pipe bombs outside the Democratic and Republican headquarters the night before the January 6 Capitol attack must remain in custody while awaiting trial.

In a memorandum opinion, the court determined that Brian Cole Jr, 30, of Woodbridge, Virginia, “poses an intolerable risk of danger to the community if released”, granting the government’s motion for pretrial detention.

Continue reading...

events.title: US homeland security condemned for using Japanese artist’s work without consent
events.summary:
Hiroshi Nagai, in a post on X, has objected to his artwork being used by the agency to promote its deportation agenda

The US Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is facing backlash once again, this time from a Japanese artist who has condemned the agency for using, without permission, his work to promote deportations.

In a post on X on New Year’s Eve, the department posted a photo featuring a pristine and empty beach with palm trees and a vintage car. Written across the photo was “America after 100 million deportations,” along with a separate caption that said: “The peace of a nation no longer besieged by the third world.”

Continue reading...

events.summary: The move comes as an escalation of a confrontation that has pitted Gulf powerhouses Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates against each other.

events.title: George Clooney gets French citizenship — and another dust-up with Trump
events.summary: The French government says it granted George and Amal Clooney citizenship because of their contributions to its international influence. Their family has primarily lived in France since 2021.

events.summary: President Trump warned Iran not to kill protesters. Iranian officials alleged the U.S. and Israel were stoking the sweeping protests, and said U.S. military bases in the region are legitimate targets.

events.summary: President Trump's pressure campaign against Venezuela is the latest in a long saga of U.S. intervention in the region that is rooted in the 1823 Monroe Doctrine — and is a mix of success and failure.

events.summary: About 40 people are dead and more than 100 are injured after a fire ripped through a New Year's Eve party at a Swiss ski resort bar. Authorities are still investigating what caused the blaze.

events.summary: Ukrainians recall their country giving up nuclear weapons in 1994 in exchange for international security promises that weren't kept. They don't want a repeat in their current negotiations with Russia.

events.summary: A podcast by two Israelis re-examines the war in Gaza and its impact on Israeli society.

events.summary: Investigators say they believe sparkling candles atop Champagne bottles ignited the fire at a Swiss ski resort when they came too close to the ceiling of a bar crowded with New Year's Eve revelers. Forty people were killed and another 119 injured.

events.summary: Taiwanese President Lai Ching-te vowed to defend the self-ruled island's sovereignty in the face of what he termed China's "expansionist ambitions," days after Beijing wrapped up live-fire military drills near its shores.

events.summary: The latest attacks on Caracas suggest regime change is top of the White House agenda when it comes to Venezuela. But the ultimate purpose may not be purely to restore democracy.

events.summary: Explosions reported in Venezuelan capital city amid tensions with the US.

events.title: US: FBI arrests man over alleged NYE attack plot
events.summary: The man had pledged loyalty to the Islamic State group and was allegedly planning a knife-and-hammer attack in North Carolina. Undercover agents foiled the terror plot, the FBI said.

events.summary: The magnitude 6.5 earthquake shook the center and south of the country, which is one of the most seismically active in the world. The capital Mexico City and tourist hotspot Acapulco were affected.

events.title: K-Pop band BTS set to make comeback in March
events.summary: The reunion marks the end of a nearly four-year hiatus. All seven members of the South Korean pop boy band BTS have now completed their mandatory military service.

events.title: Germany: Third bank robbery reported in NRW in days
events.summary: Another day, another report of a robbery at a Sparkasse bank in western Germany. This time, four safe-deposit boxes were emptied in broad daylight.

events.title: Middle Eastern governments are watching Iran's protests
events.summary: As anti-government protests continue in Iran, countries in the region are watching. Some are concerned; others sense potential opportunity.

events.title: Yemen separatists plan transition to independence by 2028
events.summary: The Southern Transitional Council said independence would be "immediate" if attacks against them continue.

events.title: Ukraine: Zelenskyy names new chief of staff
events.summary: Ukraine's popular military intelligence head, Kyrylo Budanov, has been appointed chief of staff. Meanwhile, Ukraine has reported two missile strikes in residential areas of Kharkiv.

events.title: Why plastic bans aren't working and what needs to change
events.summary: Four years after Germany phased out light plastic bags, how has the EU addressed plastic waste — and why do single-use items still pile up in takeaway restaurants, shops and the environment?

events.title: Swiss fire safety under scrutiny after Crans-Montana blaze
events.summary: After the deadly fire at the Constellation bar in the Swiss ski resort of Crans-Montana, questions are growing about the country's safety regulations.

events.title: China's BYD overtakes Tesla as world's top EV seller
events.summary: Elon Musk's Tesla has had a tough year and faced intensifying competition from Chinese and European rivals.

events.title: Swiss resort fire: Sparklers likely cause, authorities say
events.summary: The fire that tore through a bar in Crans-Montana was likely started by sparklers in Champagne bottles coming too close to the ceiling, authorities have said. Follow DW for more.

events.title: Indian workers earn highest median pay in Germany
events.summary: Indian employees have emerged as the highest earners among foreign workers in Germany, a study shows. Elevated pay levels among Indian employees are largely driven by their concentration in technical and academic roles.

events.title: Finnish police arrest 2 over undersea cable damage
events.summary: They were part of the crew aboard a cargo vessel suspected of severing a telecom cable linking Finland and Estonia.

events.title: How coup leader Doumbouya might govern democratic Guinea
events.summary: The decisive electoral victory for Mamadi Doumbouya has ended Guinea's post-coup transition to civilian rule. Can the elected president turn promises into progress for a nation rich in resources yet poor in opportunity?

events.title: Iran protests: Trump and Tehran officials exchange threats
events.summary: President Donald Trump said the US is "locked and loaded," but analysts told DW that more violence wouldn't help protesters.

events.title: CAR: Touadera expected to win 'peaceful' election
events.summary: The Central African Republic held relatively peaceful elections on December 28, widely seen as a test for President Touadera's decade in power. But can the country entrench stability and deliver economic transformation?

events.title: Germany news: Household wealth reaches record €10 trillion
events.summary: German households are holding record levels of financial assets amid economic uncertainty. Meanwhile, the number of illegal border entries in Germany has decreased by over 50% in the past two years. DW has more.

events.title: Amsterdam church destroyed by New Year's blaze
events.summary: The beloved 154-year-old Vondel Church in Amsterdam was devastated by a massive fire that erupted shortly after midnight on New Year's Day.

events.title: Ukraine updates: Zelenskyy says Russia fired 200 drones overnight
events.summary: Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Russia's strikes show the urgent need for air defense in Ukraine. Meanwhile, the Kremlin blamed Kyiv for a deadly drone strike on a hotel in the occupied Kherson region.

events.title: Bulgaria joins Eurozone despite opposition
events.summary: Bulgaria became the 21st member of the currency union, bringing the number of people using the single European currency to more than 350 million.

events.title: Anthony Joshua discharged from hospital after Nigeria crash
events.summary: The British heavyweight sustained injuries in a car crash that killed two of his friends.

events.title: What to know about 2026 European Capitals of Culture
events.summary: This year, Oulu, Finland, and Trencin, Slovakia, will become Europe's cultural flagships. Learn more about how Europe's Capitals of Culture program brings lasting change to cities.

events.title: Conscription, pensions and AfD on Germany's 2026 agenda
events.summary: Pensions, migration and conscription will continue to dominate domestic politics in Germany this year. Above all, the focus will be on how the far-right AfD fares in upcoming state elections in the former East Germany.

events.title: Germany: Merz says 2026 can be a 'year of new beginnings'
events.summary: Chancellor Friedrich Merz touched on war in Ukraine, increased defense spending, changing ties to the US, technological upheaval, industrial stagnation, sluggish reforms, migration and more in his New Year's address.

events.title: France plans social media ban for children under 15: reports
events.summary: After Australia's world-first social-media ban for minors, France has drafted a similar law to block under-15s from major platforms, which could take effect from September.

events.title: Ukraine updates: Kyiv says it struck Russia's oil facilities
events.summary: According to officials in Kyiv, Ukrainian long-range drones struck an oil depot north of Moscow, as well as an oil refinery and an oil terminal in Russia's southern Krasnodar region.

events.title: Women get drunk faster than men due to biology not tolerance
events.summary: At the same table, with the same drinks, women often get drunk faster than men — and alcohol can affect women's brains differently, making its effects stronger, sometimes more rewarding. But also more addictive.

events.title: A German tip for your New Year's resolutions
events.summary: Starting off the year with ambitious plans to become a better person is a widespread Western tradition. What are the most popular resolutions in Germany? And here's how the German language can help you deal with yours.

events.title: Finland seizes vessel suspected of damaging undersea cable
events.summary: European countries are on high alert following a series of suspected sabotage attacks on underwater cables and pipelines.

events.title: Six ways the 2026 World Cup will be different
events.summary: The United States is set to host the 2026 World Cup, along with Canada and Mexico. DW fills you in on why this tournament will be different than its predecessors.

events.title: Fact check: Content farm videos on Merz, Starmer and Trump
events.summary: Fake videos of political leaders often go viral online. DW's Fact check department analyzes how content farms use algorithm-driven formats, and what narratives they reinforce.

events.title: Eurostar back on track after Channel Tunnel power fault
events.summary: The operator of the train service connecting Britain with continental Europe has warned that delays may persist as travelers head out in the run-up to the New Year.

events.title: Almost half of all Germans want a ban on fireworks
events.summary: In Germany, it's only permitted to sell fireworks in the three days leading up to New Year's Eve. Some line up early to buy them, while others have safety concerns and want to see them banned altogether.

events.title: Germany: €30 million stolen in elaborate bank vault heist
events.summary: Investigators have been piecing together how burglars drilled into a secure area from outside and ransacked thousands of safe-deposit boxes. Police say the evidence points to a highly organized operation.

events.title: Turkey detains 357 suspects after 'Islamic State' clashes
events.summary: Turkish police have made hundreds of arrests in nationwide raids against suspected "Islamic State" networks. The sweep followed hours-long street fighting that left police and militants dead.

events.title: Cyprus back at the helm of EU Council presidency
events.summary: After 14 years, Cyprus takes over the rotating presidency of the Council of the European Union on January 1. It will lead during a politically sensitive moment, and aims to shape the EU's role on the global stage.

events.title: Eurostar suspends 'all trains' between London and Europe
events.summary: Eurostar suspended services in the ⁠tunnel that links Britain and continental Europe. The company warned earlier of disruptions due to an overhead power supply issue.

events.title: Sudan defying war to bring joy at AFCON 2025
events.summary: A brutal civil war has been raging in Sudan since 2023. The national football team is participating in the Africa Cup of Nations in Morocco with more than just sporting success in mind.

events.title: What challenges does the world economy face in 2026?
events.summary: From trade tensions and high debt burdens to fears of an AI stocks bubble, the global economy will face an array of risks that could dampen growth in the new year.

events.title: George and Amal Clooney get French citizenship
events.summary: The Hollywood star, now a dual US-French citizen, has previously praised France's strict privacy laws, saying they protect his children from paparazzi.

events.title: Ukraine updates: Putin house attack claim threatens talks
events.summary: Peace talks to end the war in Ukraine were dealt a setback after Russia claimed that Ukrainian forces launched a drone strike on one of Vladimir Putin's residences. Follow DW for the latest.

events.title: Russia opens new Mariupol theater after devastating siege
events.summary: The bombing of the Mariupol Drama Theater became a symbol of Russia's three-month siege of the city. Exiled Ukrainian municipal authorities condemned inauguration of the new theater as "singing and dancing on bones."

events.title: Taiwan heavily reliant on Russian energy for chip manufacturing
events.summary: The island imports significant qualities of Russian naphtha, a fossil-fuel derivative needed in the high-tech sector. Until recently, it also sourced much of its coal from Russia.

events.title: UK boxer Anthony Joshua injured in car crash in Nigeria
events.summary: The former Olympic champion was in a car that was involved in an accident in Nigeria. Joshua will face countryman Tyson Fury in 2026.

events.title: Baby, you're a fire hazard: Fireworks stash seized in Berlin
events.summary: Local police said that a Berlin man bragged to guests that he kept large quantities of fireworks, which led to them receiving a tip.

events.title: New Year's Eve: How to make resolutions for 2026
events.summary: Quit smoking, exercise more, eat healthier: Every January 1, we plan to do great things over the next year — only to fail most of the time. Here's how to make sure your New Year's resolutions work out.

events.title: Lufthansa and the role of big business in the Holocaust
events.summary: German airline Lufthansa is one of many big-name brands that collaborated with the Nazis during the Holocaust. As the airline celebrates its 100th anniversary, why does its Nazi past continue to fly under the radar?

events.title: Bulgaria joining eurozone is big deal
events.summary: The southeastern European country is set to ditch its national currency in favor of the euro. But while Bulgaria's economy has improved, mismanagement and corruption remain rampant.

events.title: Aurora lights: The science behind the dazzling nighttime spectacle
events.summary: The northern and southern lights have been treating sky watchers to spectacular shows. But what causes the colors, and why shouldn't you whistle at the aurora?

events.title: AI chatbots are 'alarmingly' biased against dialect speakers
events.summary: Don't speak perfect Oxford English? You may face "shocking" levels of discrimination when using large language models, researchers have found. New customized AI models could be the answer.

events.title: Climate coverage shrinks amid Trump's clean energy misinformation
events.summary: A strong majority of Americans say they're worried about the climate. So why do they hear so little about it in the news?

events.title: Kosovo: Kurti wins snap election, signalling end of impasse
events.summary: Prime Minister Kurti's governing Self-Determination party won nearly 50% of the vote, results showed with most of the votes counted. It is not yet clear whether he will be able to form a cabinet without a coalition.

events.title: Brigitte Bardot: Actor, icon, controversial activist
events.summary: French actress, singer and model Brigitte Bardot became an icon of the 1960s by portraying sexually emancipated characters. The animal rights activist also harbored polarizing political views.

events.title: French actress and activist Brigitte Bardot dies aged 91
events.summary: The French screen legend appeared in 56 films before ending her career in 1973 and dedicating herself to animal rights activism.

events.title: German company Miele to sell more refurbished appliances
events.summary: The secondhand smartphone market has grown significantly in recent years, but other, bulkier items like washing machines are less frequently refurbished and resold. That could soon be changing.

events.title: Germany's COVID-19 response under scrutiny
events.summary: A parliamentary inquiry has been looking into the policy decisions made to contain the coronavirus pandemic in Germany. The decisions made by key leaders from the time are being questioned.

events.title: Achraf Hakimi and football's growing issue: playing time
events.summary: According to a new FIFPRO report, Morocco and Paris Saint-Germain star Achraf Hakimi is a footballer at his limit, having had a season that lasted nearly a whole year. After an injury, he is now at AFCON with Morocco.

events.title: Germany at the 2026 World Cup: What next?
events.summary: Now that they have qualified and drawn in group E, Germany head into the final part of their 2026 World Cup preparations. Here's what to know.

events.title: Why Germany struggles to go digital
events.summary: Germany still leans on fax machines and paperwork for basic public services. How can a nation of tech pioneers be so slow to adopt digital government?

events.title: Peak oil: Why the world can't break its fossil fuel habit
events.summary: Climate change shifted the oil production debate from scarcity to demand. If countries do not deliver on ambitious green pledges, one expert predicts that production may peak within two years, forcing a chaotic decline.

events.title: Berlin: Archaeological finds illuminate the city's medieval past
events.summary: A brand-new museum showcases the many fascinating medieval artefacts that archaeologists are finding underneath the German capital.

events.title: Munich surfers abandon attempt to restart Eisbach wave
events.summary: City authorities are putting up unnecessary resistance to restoring the world-famous surf spot, the local sports association said.

events.title: Football: Afghan women make statement on international stage
events.summary: Afghanistan's female footballers have been fighting in exile to get back to playing internationally for years. Earlier this year, their moment arrived, but their mission is far from complete.

events.title: Germany's empty churches repurposed as congregations shrink
events.summary: The number of practicing Christians in Germany is falling. The result is surplus churches. What happens to these empty houses of worship?

events.title: Can dogs really sense danger?
events.summary: Research shows what canines really can sense — and how social media and human projection fuel belief in their supernatural abilities.

events.title: From Ukraine to US: Germany's 2026 foreign policy challenges
events.summary: Germany enters 2026 facing a world in upheaval. Whether navigating relations with the United States, Ukraine, China or Middle Eastern governments, Germany is struggling to keep pace with rapid geopolitical shifts.

events.title: The Christmas truce of 1914: When the guns fell silent
events.summary: On Christmas Eve 1914, battling German and British soldiers laid down their arms and sang Christmas carols together — a brief moment of peace in the midst of war.

events.title: Germany's far-right AfD may seize regional power in 2026
events.summary: The Alternative for Germany (AfD) will seek power in next year's state elections. Civil society groups are alarmed, as are security services, which have found that some of its factions represent extremist threats.

events.title: 7 mysterious languages that have yet to be deciphered
events.summary: Indus, Rongorongo, Linear A: Some ancient writing systems cannot be deciphered. Can artificial intelligence help crack the codes of the past?

events.title: How Germany's Deutsche Bahn aims to fix chronic delays
events.summary: German trains used to run like clockwork. Today, delays are the rule, not the exception. As public anger is boiling over, what went wrong with a system once envied worldwide, and why are the Swiss getting it right?

events.title: Ryanair faces massive fine in Italy over 'abusive strategy'
events.summary: Italy's competition authority AGCM claims the budget airline blocked payment methods and mass-deleted accounts to manipulate travel agencies and force them into partnerships. Ryanair has pledged to appeal the fine.

events.title: North Korea's Kim Jong Un, daughter open luxury resort
events.summary: Five new hotels were opened in Samjiyon, near the Chinese border, with Kim Jong Un praising the "rising status" of North Korea's people.

events.title: This is how Christmas is celebrated at the Vatican
events.summary: This year, Pope Leo XIV will lead the Christmas celebrations at the Vatican for the first time. But the popular Christmas traditions at the heart of the Roman Catholic Church remain unchanged.

events.title: Why Trump backs Bayer in Roundup weedkiller cancer battle
events.summary: The Trump administration has diverged from the position of former US President Joe Biden, throwing its weight behind German chemical giant Bayer in its courtroom battle over the pesticide Roundup.

events.title: AFCON: A 3,000-kilometer bike ride to catch the opener
events.summary: The Africa Cup of Nations is drawing thousands of fans to Morocco, and one chose an unusual way to get there. Moroccan fan Ismail Skira cycled thousands of kilometers from Paris for the opening match.

events.title: Christmas in the air: Why scents spark emotions and memories
events.summary: The scent of fresh pine and apple cider makes you think of the holidays at grandma's house? You're not alone. Smells are our strongest sensory trigger for memories — both happy and painful.

events.title: Germany registers over 1,000 suspicious drone flights in 2025
events.summary: Drone sightings this year have disrupted German airports, causing headaches for travelers. Germany has ordered special anti-aircraft tanks to combat the unmanned aerial vehicles.

events.title: AI language models duped by poems
events.summary: A new study has shown that prompts in the form of poems confuse AI models like ChatGPT, Gemini and Claude — to the point where sometimes, security mechanisms don't kick in. Are poets the new hackers?

events.title: Germany: 1,600 asylum requests by people rejected at border
events.summary: The German government said hundreds of people turned away at the border later applied for asylum. Meanwhile, Berlin's mayor is warning New Year's Eve's trouble makers. DW has the latest.

events.title: Germany trains immigrant teachers to fill gaps in schools
events.summary: Germany is desperately looking for teachers. And many migrants and refugees were once teachers in their home country. A program in Cologne — and four other cities — is hoping to create a win-win situation.

events.title: How Georgian creatives are fighting for their freedom
events.summary: Artists in Georgia are weary but defiant as they face arbitrary arrests, tough new laws and financial hardship from the country's repressive government.

events.title: 'Avatar': How the Na'vi language was constructed
events.summary: Very few people get to invent a new language that is heard by millions: DW talked to linguist Paul Frommer about how he developed the "Avatar" aliens' language.

events.title: Perfume's multicultural journey: From antiquity to TikTok
events.summary: Though often marketed through a Eurocentric lens, perfume's multilayered history spans Mesopotamia, India, Egypt and Europe, besides being retold on PerfumeTok.

events.title: Labor rights in Europe: Who's working over Christmas?
events.summary: From the number of paid days off to the size of the Christmas bonus, not all European countries are equal for workers over the holidays.

events.title: Christmas brings rise in domestic violence in Germany
events.summary: For many women, the holiday season is the most dangerous time of the year. Stress, financial worries, and cramped living conditions increase the risk of domestic violence. Women's shelters are overstretched.

events.title: Not just hocus pocus: when words were used to treat the sick
events.summary: Incantations were not only meant to ward off demons, but also to calm patients. A look into medical history reveals what lies behind the idea of tooth worms and the power of utterances like "hocus pocus."

events.title: 3I/ATLAS: Interstellar comet comes closest to Earth
events.summary: Sometimes "the universe comes to us," writes the European Space Agency. On Friday it came really close, when comet 3l/ATLAS passed by us at a ― relatively ― short distance. What exactly is this interstellar visitor?

events.title: Netflix vs. Paramount takeover battle for Warner Bros.: What's at stake?
events.summary: The multi-billion dollar bidding war to acquire Warner Bros. may soon be over. How are the negotiations connected to Harry Potter, Trump, TikTok — and the future of cinema?

events.title: Germany news: Tendency to save money highest since 2008
events.summary: A new poll suggests consumers are returning to economic uncertainty, amid rising inflation fears and debates about the future of pensions. Meanwhile, lawmakers are discussing German-US relations.

events.title: German business bankruptcies hit decade high amid downturn
events.summary: Business bankruptcies have climbed to an 11-year high, with small firms hardest hit by Germany's anemic growth. Economists warn of job losses but see tentative signs that the insolvency wave may be leveling off.

events.title: Five things to know about AFCON
events.summary: Excellent infrastructure, ambitious teams, young stars and veterans who are far from finished — the 35th edition of AFCON promises plenty.

events.title: Can Santa Claus survive in a melting world?
events.summary: As climate change warms the planet, snowy winters are becoming less certain in Europe. Those looking for classic Christmas traditions are learning to adapt.

events.title: Germany: Magdeburg Christmas market 1 year after attack
events.summary: In the eastern city of Magdeburg, people are still grieving one year after an attack on the Christmas market killed six people. But residents are also trying to carry on despite the heightened security.

events.title: Plane owned by ex-NASCAR driver Greg Biffle crashes in US
events.summary: A small aircraft owned by Greg Biffle crashed and exploded while attempting to land at Statesville Regional Airport in North Carolina. Seven people died in the crash, including the 56-year-old retired NASCAR driver.

events.title: Pioneering gay rights filmmaker Rosa von Praunheim dies at 83
events.summary: His 1971 film "It Is Not the Homosexual Who Is Perverse, but the Society in Which He Lives" is widely credited with triggering the modern gay rights movement in German-language countries.

events.title: Bayern Munich buy ex-Bundesliga stadium for women's team
events.summary: Bayern Munich are set to purchase a larger stadium for their women's team. The club's CEO described the move as "another milestone" for Bayern's women's program.

events.title: Women's health suffers, bearing the brunt of household labor
events.summary: Even as economic roles shift in romantic partnerships, women still shoulder most of the labor at home. Research suggests this is a burden affecting women's health, leading to emotional fatigue and depression.

events.title: Euro 2029 in Germany about more than profit margins
events.summary: Hosting Euro 2029 is a chance for women's football in Germany to leave a legacy beyond profit and prove investment in women is smart move.

events.title: Cheaper, cleaner energy drives Germany's balcony-solar boom
events.summary: The home-fitted renewable-energy sources are inexpensive and easy to install, and reduce electricity costs. Here's what can be learned from their surging popularity in Germany.

events.title: Merz touts EU-Mercosur deal while France, Italy protest
events.summary: The EU-Latin America trade deal has been in the making for a quarter of a century. Though Germany's chancellor called for its completion, France and Italy said it would be "premature" to sign.

events.title: Wealthy nations curb labor migration as demand surges
events.summary: Even before Donald Trump returned to the White House, anti-immigration politics were reshaping migration flows to high-income countries. Borders have been tightened despite economies facing urgent labor shortages.

events.title: Silver: Why the price of 'poor man's gold' hit a record
events.summary: Silver just reached an all-time high of $67. Although gold has eclipsed the white metal as a store of value, DW explores why silver is regaining global relevance.

events.title: Germany news: Lawmakers back €50 billion defense package
events.summary: The Bundestag budget committee has signed off on more than €50 billion in military purchases. The Cabinet is proposing tighter rules for welfare recipients.

events.title: Venezuela blockade: What it would mean for the Maduro regime and oil markets
events.summary: US President Donald Trump has threatened Venezuela with a naval blockade to thwart its oil exports — a move that would hit the Maduro government hard but may leave global oil markets unfazed.

events.title: Why US giant Chevron, not China, may save oil-rich Venezuela
events.summary: Chevron is driving Venezuela's oil rebound while China is pulling back. As the fate of President Nicolas Maduro grows uncertain, Washington's renewed leverage is reshaping the country's economic and geopolitical future.

events.title: Louvre partially back in action despite walkout
events.summary: Louvre workers voted to extend a strike as security scrutiny at the world famous museum intensifies.

events.title: Beethovenhalle reopens: The return of a German cultural icon
events.summary: After almost 10 years of renovation, Bonn's Beethovenhalle is back to its former splendor. Opened in the late 1950s, it soon became an important symbol of democracy in the newly founded Federal Republic of Germany.

events.title: AFCON offers hope after World Cup heartbreak
events.summary: Several established African teams ,like Nigeria, did not qualify for World Cup 2026 despite an expanded format. The Africa Cup of Nations, which begins this weekend, offers a different challenge and a chance to build.

events.title: Under-fire FIFA announces $60 World Cup tickets, for the few
events.summary: The good news? FIFA responded to outrage at the most expensive World Cup ever with discount tickets comparable to the cost of a normal game for "loyal fans." The bad news? It's for a tiny share of the tickets.

events.title: Why Germany's auto capitals face financial crisis
events.summary: The crisis in Germany’s revered car industry is taking a toll on its wealthiest regions — and hitting the pocketbooks of residents.

events.title: Messi's India tour and rise of the solo athlete sports brand
events.summary: In 2025, many global sports stars went on promotional tours purely to support their individual brands. Lionel Messi's tour of India is a reminder of how sport is changing.

events.title: Gas-loving Trump cedes electric car market to China
events.summary: Donald Trump is pushing gas guzzlers over EVs — in spite of climate and cost concerns. China is now set to race further ahead into an electrified automotive future.

events.title: Medical experts are pushing back on new US vaccine policy
events.summary: US health agencies under Robert F Kennedy Jr. and American medical groups are in conflict over childhood vaccination policy. At the heart of the clash is a long debunked, persistent myth about vaccine safety.

events.title: Why China's property crash must be kept top secret
events.summary: As home sales continue to plummet, Beijing has curbed independent reporting of real estate figures. The gag order masks a deepening property slump that continues to erode household wealth and strain China's banks.

events.title: Jane Austen at 250: From Regency roots to TikTok reels
events.summary: The English author's works fuel feminist debates, rom-coms and TikTok memes, proving her satire still lands across diverse cultural contexts more than two centuries on.

events.title: How the world's first global trader, Jakob Fugger, got rich
events.summary: Some 500 years ago, Jakob Fugger was the richest man alive. The German financed emperors and popes, and reshaped global trade and banking to set the economic course for the modern world.

events.title: What Russia's 'undesirable' designation means for DW
events.summary: Russia has designated Deutsche Welle an "undesirable organization." How can users stay in touch with DW without risking prosecution by Russian authorities?

events.title: Germany: 5 arrested for suspected Christmas market plot
events.summary: The five men are suspected of planning an Islamist-motivated attack on a Christmas market in southern Germany, the Munich public prosecutor's office said.

events.title: A pre-Christmas warning: Cheap toys can pose health hazard
events.summary: For kids, presents are meant to be a source of happiness and fun. But some plastic gifts can be a health risk. Here's why.

events.title: Can Lionel Messi's visit boost Indian football?
events.summary: As Lionel Messi embarks on a four-city tour of India, the footballing community there is hoping it will have a long-term impact on the state of global game in a country where cricket remains king.

events.title: Germany's housing market 'contaminated' by widespread racism
events.summary: Black and Muslim people are disproportionately discriminated against on the real estate market in Germany, according to a new study. Just having a foreign-sounding name can lead to fewer apartment viewings.

events.title: What is Hanukkah and how is it celebrated?
events.summary: Starting on December 14, Jews will celebrate the eight-day festival of Hanukkah, commemorating the rededication of Jerusalem's Second Temple in 200 B.C.

events.title: Holiday stargazing: meteor showers and supermoons ahead
events.summary: One of the biggest meteor showers of the year will peak in mid-December, ahead of an early January supermoon.

events.title: Catastrophic US floods linked to hotter climate
events.summary: Rising temperatures and extreme rainfall might not seem connected, but they often are. Here's how.

events.title: African Youth Games important, but sustainability is key
events.summary: Seven years after the last edition, Africa's sports stars of tomorrow are getting the chance to compete and develop their talent in Angola.

events.title: India's 2026 space bid: Three Gaganyaan missions by March
events.summary: Can India overcome years of delays to finally send its own spacecraft astronauts into orbit? That depends on crucial launches in the coming months.

events.title: Goodbye climate protection? How the EU is weakening its Green Deal
events.summary: European industrial and agricultural concerns are facing diluted environmental regulations, while the bloc as a whole has reduced its climate targets. What's at stake and how do far-right parties feature in the mix?

events.title: FBL aiming to take women's football in Germany to new level
events.summary: The football clubs that make up the Bundesliga have gone it alone in forming a new league organization to better develop and market the women's game in Germany.

events.title: Crude oil shoots from damaged pipeline in eastern Germany
events.summary: Brandenburg's state Environment Ministry warned of a "large oil spill" after a pipeline accident. It said that emergency services were on site and that details on the size and cause of the spill were not yet available.

events.title: Germany: Activists upset Chancellor Merz with CDU memorial
events.summary: A political artists' collective has placed a statue of murdered politician Walter Lübcke outside CDU headquarters. Lübcke was killed by a supporter of the far-right AfD, which the activists are warning against.

events.title: Too close to Trump? FIFA President Infantino under pressure
events.summary: FairSquare has accused FIFA President Gianni Infantino of repeatedly violating political neutrality. The NGO is calling for an investigation, also because of a peace prize awarded to Donald Trump.

events.title: Are mosquitoes the most dangerous animals in the world?
events.summary: Malaria, dengue, Zika virus and West Nile fever are all diseases that can be spread by mosquitoes. Hundreds of thousands of people die from such infections every year.

events.title: RB Leipzig make Tatjana Haenni Bundesliga's first woman CEO
events.summary: RB Leipzig's appointment of Tatjana Haenni makes her the first woman to hold the post of CEO at a Bundesliga club.

events.title: New strain of mpox virus: What you need to know
events.summary: A hybrid form of mpox has been identified in the UK. Health professionals are not surprised that the sexually transmitted virus has evolved but say it's a reminder of the need for precaution.

events.title: Poland: A trillion‑dollar player knocking on the G20's door
events.summary: Poland has been invited to observe the G20 summit in Miami next year. Full membership in the elite club may still be years away, but could it finally put Central Europe on the global map?

events.title: UN environment head warns of climate complacency
events.summary: Trillions of dollars could be gained every year and millions of lives saved from protecting the climate and environment, according to the UN. DW speaks to Inger Andersen about what might help us get there.

events.title: Why Japan's economic woes spark global market concern
events.summary: Japan's PM Sanae Takaichi wants to spend big to boost sluggish growth, despite the country's already huge debt load. With bond yields already rising, a sudden spike could shock the financial world well beyond Japan.

events.title: Tropical cyclones: Why are some countries more at risk?
events.summary: When tropical storms make headlines, certain countries and regions are repeatedly part of the story. Why is that and what fuels cyclones and their paths?

events.title: Sports clubs in Germany: Unique thanks to their coaches
events.summary: The culture of German sports clubs is like no other. Thanks to volunteer work, you can participate in and train for almost any sport at a low cost. Enthusiastic coaches are crucial to this.

events.title: New AI model can predict 5-year breast cancer risk
events.summary: A new AI model can predict a person's risk of developing breast cancer up to five years in advance by analyzing mammograms. This could make screening much more effective.

events.title: New discovery: The 'sacred boundary' surrounding Stonehenge
events.summary: Long thought to be an assortment of mysterious holes near Stonehenge, researchers have now used new technologies to better understand the culture that dug a circle of ditches around the monument in southern England.

events.title: US State Dept. says Venezuelan President Maduro will 'face justice'
events.summary: President Donald Trump claimed on social media that the U.S. had successfully conducted large-scale strikes in Venezuela, capturing President Nicolás Maduro and his wife, who were reportedly flown out of the country. Earlier, Maduro accused the U.S. of causing a series of explosions in Caracas and other areas and declared a state of emergency. Around 2 a.m. local time, explosions and the sound of aircraft were reported over the capital, with smoke rising from a military base hangar and parts of the city losing power. The developments come amid an increased U.S. military presence in the region, reportedly targeting suspected drug-trafficking vessels linked to Venezuela. Peter O'Brien has the latest.

events.title: Crans-Montana fire: 16 French nationals injured, nine unaccounted for
'Rioters must be put in their place,' says Iran’s Khamenei as death toll reaches at least 10
events.summary: Iran’s supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei addressed the country’s protests on Saturday, insisting that “rioters must be put in their place".  At least 10 people have been killed in the protests so far, including members of the security services, according to official figures.

events.title: Venezuela: Trump says "Maduro has been captured and flown out" of the country
events.summary: The Venezuelan government on Saturday demanded "immediate proof of life" of President Nicolas Maduro and his wife Cilia Flores after the US announced he had been captured and taken out of the country. Maduro's whereabouts remain unknown after the US conducted a "large-scale strike" earlier in the day with multiple explosions and aircraft-like sounds reported across the capital Caracas. Member of the Sciences Po's Political Observatory of Latin America, Eduardo Rios, and journalist Noris Argotte Sodo, explain further.

events.title: French authorities probe X chatbot Grok over AI-generated nude images
events.summary: The controversial X chatbot Grok has come under renewed scrutiny over its use of generative AI to create images that digitally remove clothing from young women and girls, as well as some men. French government ministers have reported the material to prosecutors and to the media regulator ARCOM, which will assess whether the content breaches the European Union’s Digital Services Act, as journalists from France 2 and Simon Mortiz investigate the issue further.

events.title: Trump says Maduro 'captured and flown out' of Venezuela
events.summary: US President Donald Trump announced on Saturday that Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro has been captured after the US conducted a "large-scale strike" on the country. Maduro had declared a state of emergency earlier in the day, accusing the United States of a “very serious military aggression” after multiple explosions and aircraft-like sounds were reported across the capital Caracas. France24 journalist Shirli Sitbon explains further.

events.title: Ukraine hosts security talks in Kyiv after strike hit Kharkiv on Friday
events.summary: As the war in Ukraine enters the new year, Russian bombardments continue to hit Ukrainian cities, with authorities reporting on Friday that residential areas in Kharkiv were targeted. Amid Russia’s largest battlefield gains since 2022, Ukraine has ordered the evacuation of 3,000 children from the Dnipro and Zaporizhia regions. Caroline Baum reports.

events.title: India: Contamined water blamed as diarrhoea outbreak kills 10 in Indore
events.summary: At least 10 people have died and more than 250 others have been hospitalized in a diarrhoea outbreak in the central Indian city of Indore, according to local health officials, who say the illness was caused by contaminated drinking water. Residents have complained that authorities have failed to address longstanding problems with the sewage system, which they believe contributed to the outbreak. Peter O'Brien tells us more.

events.title: Saudi airstrikes kill seven as rift with UAE-backed separatists deepens in Yemen
events.summary: Separatist forces in Yemen say at least seven people were killed in Saudi airstrikes on Friday, as tensions deepen between regional allies. The strikes come while the Saudi-backed governor of Hadramout province says “peaceful” efforts are underway to retake military bases abandoned by Emirati-backed separatists, highlighting the latest escalation in the rift between Riyadh and Abu Dhabi. Once united in their campaign against Houthi rebels, the two Gulf powers are now backing rival factions in Yemen’s ongoing conflict. Carys Garland reports the latest.

events.title: Crans-Montana: About 40 killed, 119 injured in fire
events.summary: As Switzerland mourns, authorities are continuing to investigate the cause of the deadly fire and now believe it was triggered by sparklers placed on champagne bottles that came too close to the bar’s ceiling. Investigators are also examining whether the venue’s materials met fire safety regulations. Meanwhile, families anxiously await news of their loved ones, as some victims have been transferred to specialized burn units in hospitals in France and Italy, while six people remain unidentified. Simon Mortiz and Valériane Gauthier have more.

events.title: Switzerland: Investigators examine nightclub fire origin sparkler link
events.summary: As Switzerland mourns, authorities are continuing to investigate the cause of the deadly fire and now believe it was triggered by sparklers placed on champagne bottles that came too close to the bar’s ceiling. Investigators are also examining whether the venue’s materials met fire safety regulations. Meanwhile, families anxiously await news of their loved ones, as some victims have been transferred to specialized burn units in hospitals in France and Italy, while six people remain unidentified. France24 journalist Olivia Bizot reports the latest from Crans-Montana.

events.title: US launches military strikes on Venezuela after Trump's threats against Maduro
events.summary: Venezuela has accused the United States of launching attacks after a series of explosions struck Caracas and other regions, prompting President Nicolás Maduro to say his government had repelled what he called U.S. military aggression and to declare a state of emergency. The blasts were reported around 2 a.m. local time, accompanied by the sound of aircraft overhead, with smoke seen rising from a military base hangar and power outages affecting parts of the capital. U.S. officials told Reuters that American forces were conducting strikes inside Venezuela, amid an expanded U.S. military presence in the region aimed at intercepting alleged drug trafficking vessels linked to the country. Washington Bureau Chief at The Guardian, David Smith, tells us more.

events.title: Zelensky names spy boss chief to head presidential administration in big shakeup
events.summary: President Volodymyr Zelenskiy named Ukraine's military intelligence chief Kyrylo Budanov as his top adviser on Friday and proposed a drone and digitalisation specialist as defence minister. The appointments were made as Kyiv seeks to strengthen its hand in U.S.-backed talks to end its nearly four-year-old conflict with Russia. France24 correspondent from Ukraine, Emmanuele Chaze, tells us the latest.

events.title: Venezuela: At least 7 explosions and low-flying aircraft heard in Caracas
events.summary: US President Donald Trump announced on Saturday that Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro has been captured after the US conducted a "large-scale strike" on the country. Maduro had declared a state of emergency earlier in the day, accusing the United States of a “very serious military aggression” after multiple explosions and aircraft-like sounds were reported across the capital Caracas. Noris Argotte Soto reports from Caracas.

events.title: Zelensky signals defense shakeup with tech-focused appointment
events.summary: President Volodymyr Zelensky has announced planned government changes, including his intention to replace Ukraine’s defense minister, a move he confirmed on Friday without providing a specific explanation. He said he has offered the post to the current minister of digital transformation, Mykhailo Fedorov, a 34-year-old political newcomer who is not widely known among the Ukrainian public. Analysts suggest the choice highlights the growing role of drones and advanced technology in Ukraine’s war strategy. Nicholas Rushworth tells us more.

events.title: 🔴 Follow live: Trump says Maduro 'captured and flown out' of Venezuela
🔴 Venezuela's Maduro declares state of emergency after US 'attack': Follow live
Live: Venezuela demands proof of life of President Maduro and wife
events.summary: The Venezuelan government on Saturday demanded "immediate proof of life" of President Nicolas Maduro and his wife Cilia Flores after the US announced he had been captured and taken out of the country. Maduro's whereabouts remain unknown after the US conducted a "large-scale strike" earlier in the day with multiple explosions and aircraft-like sounds reported across the capital Caracas. Follow our liveblog for the latest updates.

events.title: Multiple explosions, aircraft sounds reported in Venezuela’s Caracas
Trump says Venezuela's Maduro has been captured after large-scale strikes
events.summary: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro has been captured by elite US special forces troops and flown out of the country, a US official said Saturday. Maduro's capture follows a large-scale strike on the country that the Venezuelan government called an "imperialist attack".

events.title: Live: Kyiv hosts high-level security talks with Ukraine's allies
events.summary: Ukraine is set to host security advisers from around 15 countries in Kyiv on Saturday for talks on a US-brokered peace plan as President Volodymyr Zelensky said negotiations were nearing a deal, despite unresolved territorial issues and Russian claims of setbacks. Follow our liveblog for the latest updates.

events.title: Kenya: Multi-storey building collapses in Nairobi, with 4 people believed to be trapped
events.summary: A multi-storey building under construction has collapsed in Nairobi, with at least four people feared to be trapped beneath the rubble. While the cause is yet to be confirmed, building collapses are common in Nairobi, where poor construction standards and weak regulation have long been blamed. A report by the National Construction Authority found that 58% of buildings in Nairobi are unfit for habitation.  Rescue teams are on site as families plead for efforts to reach survivors to be sped up.

events.title: Ukraine's Zelensky names spy chief Kyrylo Budanov as new top aide
events.summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Friday appointed military intelligence chief Kyrylo Budanov as head of his office, following the resignation of top aide Andriy Yermak over a corruption scandal. Budanov, credited with daring operations against Russia, will focus on security, defence and diplomatic efforts amid the ongoing war.

events.title: Everything we know about US strikes on Venezuela
events.summary: The US has carried out a "large-scale strike" against Venezuela, and its leader, Nicolas Maduro, has been flown out of the country with his wife.

events.title: The US has followed through on its Venezuela threats - how did we get here?
events.summary: After months of rising tensions, a build-up of US warships in the Caribbean and escalating threats of military action, America has struck Venezuela.

events.title: Iran threatens Trump after 'locked and loaded' warning
events.summary: Donald Trump has been threatened with a "swift, decisive and comprehensive" response by Iran if the US intervenes following growing unrest in the country, with at least 10 people killed and dozens of arrests, according to reports.

events.title: How sanctions are boosting Russian wine
events.summary: You've probably never had a glass of Russian sparkling wine before. Perhaps you never even knew such a thing existed. If that's the case, Mikhail Nikolaev believes you're missing out.

events.title: Anthony Joshua's driver charged over deadly Nigeria crash
events.summary: The man behind the wheel of a car that crashed into a lorry in Nigeria, killing two passengers and injuring Anthony Joshua has been charged.

events.title: How hundreds have died in nightclub blazes caused by indoor fireworks
events.summary: The death of at least 40 people in a New Year's Eve fire in a Swiss ski resort has once again highlighted the dangers of igniting indoor fireworks in bars and nightclubs.

events.title: 'The State of South Arabia': Yemen separatists announce plan for independence

events.title: How Venezuela's global partners could react to U.S. strikes

events.title: Trump: Maduro and his wife have been 'captured and flown out of the country'
events.summary: President Trump announced on Truth Social that the U.S. “has successfully carried out a large scale strike against Venezuela” and that President Maduro and his wife have been "captured and flown out of the country." NBC News' Peter Alexander and Richard Engel report.

events.title: 'People are very very scared': Reporter in Venezuela describes reaction to explosions

events.summary: Billionaire tech executive Elon Musk’s relationship with party leaders in China is in the spotlight as the trade war ramps up. NBC News’ Janis Mackey Frayer reports on what this means for his popularity in the country.

events.title: Welcome, 2026! Here are the landmark events that will happen in the new year.

events.title: How Japan is fighting back against a surge of bear attacks
events.summary: ODATE, Japan — Before students can come out to play at his school, Yoji Hikage has to give the all clear.

events.title: At Gaza's only animal shelter, workers share what food they have with hungry dogs and cats

events.title: A murder, a manhunt and the grandmother who wouldn't stop the search for her daughter's killer
events.summary: Josephine Wentzel spent years tracking down the suspect in her daughter’s death and is now helping others grieving cold cases.

events.title: Maduro says he's open to talks with Trump but won't comment on U.S. strike on Venezuelan dock
events.summary: Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro said he was open to negotiating with the United States to combat drug trafficking.

events.title: Around 40 dead and 115 injured after fire sweeps through Swiss ski resort bar

events.title: U.S. finds Ukraine did not try to kill Putin in alleged drone strike, source says

events.title: Eyewitnesses describe mysterious explosion in northwest Venezuela

events.title: Alleged drone attack on a Putin residence offers the Kremlin a timely narrative shift

events.title: Trump warns Iran and Hamas after meeting with Netanyahu

events.title: China fires a warning to the U.S. and simulates blockade of Taiwan

events.title: Boxer Anthony Joshua injured in car crash that killed 2 in Nigeria

events.title: Russia threatens Ukraine after alleged attack on Putin's residence

events.title: As Trump and Zelenskyy meet in Florida, Kyiv hopes this time will be different
